sub_topic: Calculation of entropy change for a chemical reaction
message_1:
Calculate the entropy change for the reaction: 
2H2(g) + O2(g) → 2H2O(g)
given that the standard molar entropies of H2(g), O2(g), and H2O(g) are 130.7 J/mol.K, 205.0 J/mol.K, and 188.8 J/mol.K, respectively.
message_2:
To calculate the entropy change (ΔS) for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔS = ΣnS(products) - ΣnS(reactants)

where n is the stoichiometric coefficient and S is the standard molar entropy of each species.

For the given reaction:

2H2(g) + O2(g) → 2H2O(g)

ΔS = [2 × S(H2O(g))] - [2 × S(H2(g)) + 1 × S(O2(g))]

Now, we can plug in the given standard molar entropies:

ΔS = [2 × 188.8 J/mol.K] - [2 × 130.7 J/mol.K + 1 × 205.0 J/mol.K]

ΔS = [377.6 J/mol.K] - [261.4 J/mol.K + 205.0 J/mol.K]

ΔS = 377.6 J/mol.K - 466.4 J/mol.K

ΔS = -88.8 J/mol.K

The entropy change for the reaction is -88.8 J/mol.K.
